intro: Ocimum anisodorum, commonly known as anise basil, is a member of the Lamiaceae family and is native to the Mediterranean region. It is characterized by its aromatic, slightly licorice-scented leaves that are often used in culinary and medicinal applications. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that have a rough texture. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pale purple or white, arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the stems. Ocimum anisodorum thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for herb gardens.
